summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General with a former Federal Bureau of Prisons employee, identified as Mr. [REDACTED], on March 21, 2022. The interview is part of an OIG investigation into the events surrounding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The witness provides background on his employment history with the BOP and his role as a General Foreman/Maintenance Mechanic Supervisor at MCC New York from December 2016 to February 2019. This document is a transcript of an interview or deposition with a former Bureau of Prisons employee (referred to as MR. [REDACTED]) regarding his role and responsibilities at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The questioning focuses on clarifying whether he was officially the 'acting facility manager' after his supervisor left, and details about a camera system upgrade project at the MCC that was initiated prior to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration. This document is a deposition transcript discussing a contract for camera system upgrades at MCC New York. The conversation focuses on a contract with SigNet Technologies, delivery of equipment, installation timelines, and confusion about whether cameras and related gear were ever delivered to the facility. The witness, a former facilities manager, states he never saw any new cameras or equipment arrive and questions the delivery claims made by SigNet representatives. This is a transcript of an OIG interview with a former Bureau of Prisons employee regarding the procurement and installation of a camera system at MCC New York, specifically discussing issues with equipment delivery, storage at an offsite building (Building 4), and concerns about comm techs having unauthorized access to live camera feeds.

keyFacts: The interview is part of an official DOJ Office of the Inspector General investigation into the events surrounding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein.
The witness, a former BOP employee, worked as a General Foreman (Maintenance Mechanic Supervisor) at MCC New York from December 2016 until February 14, 2019.

The witness's direct supervisor, Facility Manager Mr. [REDACTED], left MCC New York unexpectedly after a training conference in Denver and never returned, with his departure occurring roughly a year before the witness left in February 2019.
The witness describes having to perform some facility manager functions informally after his supervisor left, with approval from higher-ups, but was never formally designated as acting or promoted.
High staff turnover at MCC New York is noted, with the witness reporting three different Associate Wardens of Operations during his tenure and the warden changing multiple times.

The interviewee's official title was General Foreman, but he informally performed duties of the Facility Manager after his supervisor left, though he was never formally promoted or designated as 'acting' in a way he considered official.

There were significant, pre-existing problems with the camera and recording systems at the MCC, including broken cameras, analog systems, and blind spots, which were known long before Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration.

A major camera system upgrade project was initiated to switch from analog to digital, add new cameras, and run new wiring. The project's cost was negotiated down from over $1 million to around $800,000.
The departure of the previous facility manager, [REDACTED], was shrouded in secrecy and related to an unresolved personal issue with the Bureau, which delayed hiring a permanent replacement.
The interviewee left the MCC in February 2019, and at that time, no new cameras or wiring from the upgrade project had been installed, though preparatory work like hanging conduit had begun.
A contract for a camera system upgrade at MCC New York was awarded to SigNet Technologies on September 21, 2018, with a total value of $698,108.

The witness, a former facilities manager, states that as of his last day on February 14, 2019, no new cameras or related equipment had been delivered or were on-site at MCC New York, contradicting claims from SigNet representatives.

Email correspondence indicates confusion and lack of tracking information regarding the delivery of camera system gear, with SigNet claiming delivery around October 2018 and installation in August 2019.
The contract initially had a delivery date of September 28, 2018, which the witness called 'totally unrealistic and irrational' given the scale of the installation.
In-house staff at MCC New York were tasked with running conduit and wiring to reduce costs, but the department was severely understaffed, impacting progress.
The interviewee reveals that camera system equipment may have been delivered to Building 4 at the Brooklyn Navy Shipyard rather than directly to MCC New York, contradicting previous assumptions.
Building 4 was used as a storage facility with walk-in freezers, coolers, and separate cages for each department's overstock supplies.
The interviewee expresses concern that comm techs at MCC New York had live camera monitoring capability in their office, which he considered a security violation compared to other institutions.
The camera system installation faced significant delays with wiring issues and had "too many hands in the pot" with multiple administrators involved.
The interview reveals institutional management issues at MCC New York, including lack of oversight at the offsite storage building and unusual access protocols for sensitive equipment.
